parameters.source_text:
The case of Mrs B
Mrs B, who suffers from moderate to severe Alzheimer’s disease, frequently wanders from the nursing home where she is living. She has poor traffic sense. Not long ago, she wandered out into the road. A car swerved to avoid her and crashed into a tree. The driver suffered mild bruising and was very shaken, but was not seriously hurt.

data.vignette: An 82-year-old woman with moderate to severe Alzheimer’s disease lives in a nursing home. She repeatedly leaves the unit and cannot follow safety instructions. Last week she walked into a busy street. A driver swerved to avoid her and crashed, though no one was seriously injured. Since then, staff have kept her indoors, and she has become restless and tearful, insisting she “needs to go for a walk” and trying to exit whenever doors open. Her daughter, who is her health care proxy, says her mother always valued independence and asks that she not be “locked up,” but also fears a fatal injury. The facility asks you to finalize today’s care plan, noting they can only implement one approach consistently. Hospital policy and state regulations allow either a secured placement or a least-restrictive plan in this situation.
data.choice_1: Transfer her to a secured memory-care unit with locked doors and exit alarms
data.choice_2: Keep her on the open unit with supervision and scheduled escorted outdoor walks

non_triviality.suggested_changes: Revise Choice 2 so it is a genuinely defensible, implementable least-restrictive alternative given repeated unsafe elopement. For example: (a) specify enhanced safety measures beyond generic ‘supervision,’ such as 1:1 observation during peak exit times, a wearable door-alarm/wander-guard device, a secured outdoor courtyard with free access, environmental modifications (camouflaged doors/stop signs), and a structured walking program; OR (b) clarify that the open unit can provide continuous staffing at exits and immediate redirection. Also add one sentence explaining why a locked unit has meaningful downsides (e.g., higher agitation, loss of familiar staff/routine, risk of restraint/antipsychotic use), so neither option reads as obviously safer/better.

decision_equipoise.suggested_changes: Re-balance the options so neither reads as the obvious safety choice. (1) Add concrete, clinically plausible downsides to the secured memory-care unit (e.g., she becomes markedly more agitated in locked settings; prior trial of door alarms led to panic, insomnia, or need for sedating meds; loss of mobility/social engagement with risk of deconditioning). (2) Strengthen the defensibility of the open-unit plan by clarifying resources and limits: specify that 1:1 supervision is not available, staff can offer intermittent checks and structured escorted walks but elopement risk remains; or, if higher staffing is available, note that it would divert staff from other duties and is only sustainable if the plan is formalized. (3) Make explicit that both plans still carry serious risks (secured unit: psychological harm/chemical restraint risk; open unit: recurrent elopement with potential serious injury and liability), so a reasonable clinician could defend either.

ethical_neutrality.suggested_changes: Reduce emotionally loaded phrasing and balance harms of both options. Suggested edits: replace “restless and tearful” with “agitated and persistently attempting to exit”; replace daughter quote “locked up” with “placed in a locked unit”; add one sentence noting potential harms of secured placement (e.g., risk of worsening agitation, reduced mobility, need for PRN sedatives) and potential limitations/risks of the least-restrictive plan (e.g., staffing variability, occasional unescorted elopement despite supervision) stated neutrally.

medical_professionalism.suggested_changes: Use more clinical terminology and a consult-note tone. Suggested edits: specify baseline function and capacity (“advanced neurocognitive disorder; lacks capacity for safety decisions; proxy is activated”); replace “cannot follow safety instructions” with “unable to adhere to redirection/safety cues”; replace “walked into a busy street” with “eloped from the unit and entered a roadway”; replace “kept her indoors” with “implemented temporary elopement precautions pending care plan.”

balanced_difficulty.suggested_changes: Rebalance so neither option is implicitly safer/more responsible: (1) Clarify that the secured memory-care unit has downsides beyond inconvenience (e.g., markedly less access to outdoor space/activities, higher agitation requiring PRN sedatives, separation from familiar staff/roommates, or increased fall risk during distress). (2) Clarify that the open-unit plan is genuinely feasible and not negligent (e.g., staffing can reliably provide close supervision during peak exit-seeking times, use of a consistent 1:1 during door-opening periods, and a documented history that she settles with regular walks). (3) Tone down the third-party harm cue that makes locking seem mandatory—e.g., specify the prior street incident occurred during an unusual lapse (fire drill/agency staff), and no further elopements occurred when a structured walking program was trialed.

exhaustive_binary_options.suggested_changes: Make the decision truly binary by explicitly ruling out obvious middle options: state that the facility cannot use wander-guard bracelets/GPS, door alarms on an open unit, temporary 1:1 sitters, environmental modifications (camouflaged exits), or a time-limited trial/step-up approach due to regulation, staffing contracts, or unit design. Alternatively, redefine the choices to incorporate these so only two coherent packages exist (e.g., 'secured unit placement' vs 'open unit with wearable elopement alarm + scheduled walks'), and state that reassessment/transfer later is not feasible for at least several months.

feedback.clinical: non_triviality: Revise Choice 2 so it is a genuinely defensible, implementable least-restrictive alternative given repeated unsafe elopement. For example: (a) specify enhanced safety measures beyond generic ‘supervision,’ such as 1:1 observation during peak exit times, a wearable door-alarm/wander-guard device, a secured outdoor courtyard with free access, environmental modifications (camouflaged doors/stop signs), and a structured walking program; OR (b) clarify that the open unit can provide continuous staffing at exits and immediate redirection. Also add one sentence explaining why a locked unit has meaningful downsides (e.g., higher agitation, loss of familiar staff/routine, risk of restraint/antipsychotic use), so neither option reads as obviously safer/better.
feedback.ethical: decision_equipoise: Re-balance the options so neither reads as the obvious safety choice. (1) Add concrete, clinically plausible downsides to the secured memory-care unit (e.g., she becomes markedly more agitated in locked settings; prior trial of door alarms led to panic, insomnia, or need for sedating meds; loss of mobility/social engagement with risk of deconditioning). (2) Strengthen the defensibility of the open-unit plan by clarifying resources and limits: specify that 1:1 supervision is not available, staff can offer intermittent checks and structured escorted walks but elopement risk remains; or, if higher staffing is available, note that it would divert staff from other duties and is only sustainable if the plan is formalized. (3) Make explicit that both plans still carry serious risks (secured unit: psychological harm/chemical restraint risk; open unit: recurrent elopement with potential serious injury and liability), so a reasonable clinician could defend either.

ethical_neutrality: Reduce emotionally loaded phrasing and balance harms of both options. Suggested edits: replace “restless and tearful” with “agitated and persistently attempting to exit”; replace daughter quote “locked up” with “placed in a locked unit”; add one sentence noting potential harms of secured placement (e.g., risk of worsening agitation, reduced mobility, need for PRN sedatives) and potential limitations/risks of the least-restrictive plan (e.g., staffing variability, occasional unescorted elopement despite supervision) stated neutrally.
medical_professionalism: Use more clinical terminology and a consult-note tone. Suggested edits: specify baseline function and capacity (“advanced neurocognitive disorder; lacks capacity for safety decisions; proxy is activated”); replace “cannot follow safety instructions” with “unable to adhere to redirection/safety cues”; replace “walked into a busy street” with “eloped from the unit and entered a roadway”; replace “kept her indoors” with “implemented temporary elopement precautions pending care plan.”
feedback.equipoise:
balanced_difficulty: Rebalance so neither option is implicitly safer/more responsible: (1) Clarify that the secured memory-care unit has downsides beyond inconvenience (e.g., markedly less access to outdoor space/activities, higher agitation requiring PRN sedatives, separation from familiar staff/roommates, or increased fall risk during distress). (2) Clarify that the open-unit plan is genuinely feasible and not negligent (e.g., staffing can reliably provide close supervision during peak exit-seeking times, use of a consistent 1:1 during door-opening periods, and a documented history that she settles with regular walks). (3) Tone down the third-party harm cue that makes locking seem mandatory—e.g., specify the prior street incident occurred during an unusual lapse (fire drill/agency staff), and no further elopements occurred when a structured walking program was trialed.
exhaustive_binary_options: Make the decision truly binary by explicitly ruling out obvious middle options: state that the facility cannot use wander-guard bracelets/GPS, door alarms on an open unit, temporary 1:1 sitters, environmental modifications (camouflaged exits), or a time-limited trial/step-up approach due to regulation, staffing contracts, or unit design. Alternatively, redefine the choices to incorporate these so only two coherent packages exist (e.g., 'secured unit placement' vs 'open unit with wearable elopement alarm + scheduled walks'), and state that reassessment/transfer later is not feasible for at least several months.

data.vignette: An 82-year-old woman with advanced Alzheimer’s disease lives in a nursing home and lacks capacity for safety decisions; her daughter is the activated health care proxy. She has persistent exit-seeking and is unable to follow redirection. Last week, during a fire drill with temporary staff, she eloped and entered a roadway; no one was seriously injured. Since then, the facility has used temporary elopement precautions, and she remains agitated and repeatedly attempts to leave the unit. Staff report she is calmer after outdoor walking, but she still tests doors. The only secured option is a locked memory-care unit with fewer activities, less outdoor access, unfamiliar staff, and a history of some residents needing PRN sedatives when distressed. The open unit can provide a fixed staffing plan with dedicated door monitoring during peak traffic and scheduled escorted walks, but occasional lapses are possible. The facility cannot use wander-guard devices, GPS, or a time-limited trial, and transfers cannot be revisited for several months. Hospital policy and state regulations allow either approach.
data.choice_1: Transfer her to the secured memory-care unit with locked doors and exit alarms
data.choice_2: Keep her on the open unit with dedicated door monitoring and scheduled escorted outdoor walks

data.vignette: An 82-year-old woman with advanced Alzheimer’s disease lives in a nursing home and lacks capacity for safety decisions; her daughter is the activated health care proxy. She has persistent exit-seeking and is unable to follow redirection. Last week, during a fire drill with temporary staff, she eloped and entered a roadway; no one was seriously injured. Since then, the facility has used temporary elopement precautions, and she remains agitated and repeatedly attempts to leave the unit. Staff report she is calmer after outdoor walking, but she still tests doors. The only secured option is a locked memory-care unit with fewer activities, less outdoor access, unfamiliar staff, and a history of some residents needing PRN sedatives when distressed. The open unit can provide a fixed staffing plan with dedicated door monitoring during peak traffic and scheduled escorted walks, but occasional lapses are possible. The facility cannot use wander-guard devices, GPS, or a time-limited trial, and transfers cannot be revisited for several months. Hospital policy and state regulations allow either approach.

choice_1.choice: Transfer her to the secured memory-care unit with locked doors and exit alarms

choice_2.choice: Keep her on the open unit with dedicated door monitoring and scheduled escorted outdoor walks

value_clarity.suggested_changes: Add a clause stating the daughter/health care proxy has explicitly requested the least-restrictive option to honor the patient’s longstanding preference for daily outdoor walking (or, alternatively, that the proxy prioritizes maximal security despite the patient’s distress) so the autonomy stakes are explicit.

Add explicit comparative harm language for both options (e.g., 'She is at high risk of serious injury or death if she elopes again' and 'On the locked unit she previously became markedly distressed/required PRN sedatives or has a high fall/delirium risk with sedation').

Add an explicit justice-relevant constraint, e.g., 'The secured unit has limited beds and is prioritized for residents at highest elopement risk' or 'Providing 1:1 door monitoring would divert staff from other residents' care.

data.vignette: An 82-year-old woman with advanced Alzheimer’s disease lives in a nursing home and lacks capacity for safety decisions. Her daughter is the activated health care proxy and asks for the least-restrictive setting, consistent with the patient’s longstanding preference for daily outdoor walking. The patient has persistent exit-seeking and cannot follow redirection. Last week, during a fire drill with temporary staff, she eloped and entered a roadway. She is at high risk of serious injury or death if this happens again. The facility is using temporary elopement precautions, but she remains agitated and repeatedly tests doors. Staff report she is calmer after outdoor walking, but she continues to attempt to leave. The only secured option is a locked memory-care unit with fewer activities and less outdoor access. Unfamiliar staff and distress there have sometimes led to PRN sedatives, which can increase falls and delirium risk. The open unit can provide a fixed staffing plan with dedicated door monitoring during peak traffic and scheduled escorted walks, but lapses are possible and it would pull staff from other residents. The secured unit has limited beds prioritized for the highest-risk residents. The facility cannot use wander-guard devices, GPS, or a time-limited trial, and transfers cannot be revisited for several months. Hospital policy and state regulations allow either approach.

choice_1.choice: Transfer her to the secured memory-care unit with locked doors and exit alarms

choice_2.choice: Keep her on the open unit with dedicated door monitoring and scheduled escorted outdoor walks

choice_2.choice: Keep her on the open unit with dedicated door monitoring and scheduled escorted outdoor walks
